awd_titl_txt: RCN: Building a Collaborative Network for Coastal Wetland Carbon Cycle Synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Tidal marshes, mangrove swamps and seagrass meadows are unique ecosystems found on coastlines worldwide. These wetlands support specialized plant, microbe and animal species that collectively form some of the Earth's most productive ecosystems, influencing the ecology of estuaries and coastal oceans. Coastal wetlands are also under severe pressure from human activity which threatens to diminish the many benefits they provide to people and aquatic food webs. Among these benefits is the fact that they remove large amounts of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and bury it in soils for centuries to millennia. Indeed, these ecosystems account for nearly 50 percent of the organic carbon buried in sediments despite occupying less than 2 percent of terrestrial area. This surprising fact suggests an opportunity: that protecting, restoring and managing coastal ecosystems could improve the ecological and social benefits they provide. The pace of research on this topic has accelerated and there is a great need to coordinate ongoing research and synthesize existing information. The goal of this Research Coordination Network (RCN) project is to advance understanding of carbon cycling in coastal wetlands by creating a central repository for sharing data, and facilitating synthesis and modeling to better predict the functioning of coastal ecosystems.
 

The Coastal Wetland Carbon Research Coordination Network will accelerate scientific discovery, advance science-informed policy, and improve coastal ecosystem management by: (1) developing a community dedicated to coastal wetland carbon science for basic research, policy development, and management, (2) exploring the ecological links among coastal wetlands, estuaries, and the atmosphere, and (3) sharing data and analysis tools that support the diverse needs of scientists, policy makers and managers. Activity 1 will establish a repository for participant-contributed data, and a central portal for downloading data from repositories of interest to the coastal carbon community. Activity 2 will create a Coastal Wetland Carbon website to attract participation of diverse users by providing a variety of resources that meet their needs. It will provide data analysis tools, a knowledge sharing resource, a video library of training modules in standard methods, a code library to support modeling, links to publications, and a webinar library. This RCN project will also provide outreach via a series of webinars and town hall gatherings at professional meetings, host a series of workshops on scientific gaps in coastal carbon, and develop a web-based tool for modeling.

por.por_cntn:
Coastal wetlands have a disproportionate impact on greenhouse gas emissions and removals relative to their area. They have the potential to sequester carbon because they are productive and can form highly organic soils under salty and oxygen-poor conditions. They are also a source of methane, a greenhouse gas many times more potent than CO2. The capacity of coastal wetlands to sequester carbon and emit methane is important to understand in this era of global change because restoring the function of degraded tidal wetlands has the potential to restart carbon sequestration and reduce CO2 and CH4 emissions. In addition, sea-level rise can either help form or destroy wetlands depending on local conditions.

At the beginning of this project the nascent field of 'Blue Carbon' research suffered from a lack of coordinated data sharing between various academic, government, and non-profit groups. This grant established the Coastal Carbon Research Coordination Network (CCRCN), which aimed to leverage existing expertise and research activities using community outreach, public data synthesis, and scientific workshops to accelerate the pace of discovery in coastal carbon science and to build a community of practice around the resulting data products.

A major aspect of this project was to establish a transparent centralized portal for sharing coastal soils data. Throughout the five years of the grant, we partnered with Smithsonian Libraries and Figshare, with our group acting as both a liaison to the coastal wetland research and policy communities and as data curators. We published 28 stable data publications with clear provenance (i.e. credit given to the people who generated the data), licenses, and digital object identifiers, all of which follows best practices and conforms to the high data standards we established for the CCRCN. This data publication effort evolved into The Coastal Carbon Library, a global data synthesis fusing individual data sources published through our efforts with data from multiple other sources into a single standardized database. Currently the database contains data from 6,691 soil profiles, from 64 countries. We also built the Coastal Carbon Atlas, an online map interface which is fully public and allows you to visualize and query the database.

In its first five years, The Coastal Carbon Library and Atlas have generated some notable successes. The database contributed to a high-profile research paper in the journal Nature showing where in the world we should expect increases in carbon burial under future sea-level rise scenarios given past patterns of carbon accumulation. The Library and Atlas also resulted in the identification the U.S. Pacific Northwest as a hot spot of coastal carbon data quantity and quality due to the high-level of participation by people in the Pacific Northwest Blue Carbon Working Group. Finally, the database structure and lessons-learned have been instrumental in establishing and informing an even larger network of Soil Data Informaticians who work across all types of terrestrial ecosystems.

Major scientific progress has been made through the CCRCN's two topical working groups, collaborations which have convened 28 scientists and engaged them long-term to work on research questions that were beyond the scope of any individual effort. The CCRCN's Soils Working Group, which convened in December 2018, developed an open-source version of the Cohort Marsh Equilibrium Model (CMEM). This is a seminal model in the field developed over decades by wetland scientists. It describes soil formation in the tidal zone as the results of feedback between sea-level rise, inundation, plant productivity and mineral trapping, collectively resulting soil elevation change. Forecasts of soil elevation are important because it is the most fundamental variable that determines whether coastal wetlands survive very high rates of sea level rise in the next century. We made this model available for the first time as a free, publicly available, fully transparent, open-source R-Package, which we believe will contribute towards improved forecasting of coastal soil carbon sequestration in the future. 

A second Methane Working Group convened in December 2019. This group produced a new synthesis of methane emissions from coastal wetlands and a suite of potential environmental drivers that affect methane emissions. Statistical analyses indicates that salinity class and soil temperature have non-linear and interacting effects that control methane emissions from tidal wetlands.  This group also revised the PEPRMnT model to predict observed surface methane and carbon dioxide fluxes in tidal wetlands. PEPRMnT now includes functions that describe the inhibitory effect of salinity-associated sulfate concentration on methane production. As an initial demonstration of the updated model, PEPRMnT was fit with data from three continuously monitored sites, then validated with independent data from three different sites.  

Broader impacts of this work included extensive training and leadership opportunities for early career scientists, and the communication of the importance of 'Blue Carbon' ecosystems to policy makers. Overall, we succeeded in building a robust community of practice around coastal carbon data synthesis.
